text: If today the newspapers as a whole are discussing how many miles separate the Red Army from Warsaw, if politicians and lovers of politics discuss how many months separate us from the defeat of Germany, it is because Russia held out in 1941 and '42.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: [Early '43] Folksvillen (Swedish journal): We published Ilya Ehrenburg's critique of Hitler's speech, omitting offensive passages. Despite no initial objections, authorities later held a cabinet meeting and ordered the confiscation of all copies.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: A guideline issued to the 3.6 million German soldiers on the eastern front called for “ruthless and energetic measures against Bolshevik agitators, guerrillas, saboteurs, Jews, and total elimination of all active and passive resistance.” In essence, these were instructions for mass murder, not war.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Hitler invaded the USSR on 22 June 1941. Stalin had ignored more than 80 warnings believing Hitler could never trick him. Stalin was so disoriented, it was Foreign Minister Molotov who announced the news to the nation. Soviet citizens rushed to enlist.
sourceAPA: Grossman, V. (2010). A Writer At War: Vasily Grossman with the Red Army 1941-1945. United Kingdom: Random House.

text: The USSR suffered the highest losses in WWII at ~26 million (13.5% of total population). In contrast: US lost 418,500 (0.32%), UK 450,700 (0.94%) & France 567,000 (1.35%). Axis casualties were also high: Japan lost 3.1 million (3.67%), Germany 6.6-8 million (7.9%). Nearly every Soviet family was devastated by the war.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.

text: 1942 | I wrote sharp articles for the News Chronicle, the Evening Standard and the Daily Herald, saying what our people thuoght of the Allies' inaction.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: 1944 | In Rastenburg I saw a Red Army man furiously plunging his bayonet into a wax model of a girl that stood in the window of a gutted shop. I shouted at him, 'Stop it! The German are looking!' He yelled back,'The bastards tortured my wife to death.' He was a Beylorussian.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [F]or me victory is neither marble nor granite nor verses, but an army nurse in a trench coat, her feet sore and bleeding, her eyes inflamed from sleepless nights.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Moscow | July-3-1941 | There are many rumors, both good and bad. One tells you that the Red Army has reached Warsaw, another that the Germans are near Moscow.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Moscow | July-13-1941 | A captured corporal was brought to HQ. He glanced around with disdain and said: 'Surrender, and I promise you the Führer's pardon.'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Moscow | July-3-1941 | Passing a church, I saw people praying for the Red Army's victory. A policeman urged a woman, 'Go inside and pray.' She retorted, 'I'm an unbeliever—just going in for information.'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Moscow | July-22-1941 | Sixteen-year-old boys and girls have gone off to Vyazma; under a shower of German bombs they are digging anti-tank trenches.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Dec-2-1941 | Article in Red Star, 'An Answer to Ribbentrop': These promoters of progress threw out of their country the greatest scientist of our time—Einstein [...] have burned hundreds of thousands of books [...] have gone back to genealogical trees.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Dec-22-1941 | Article in Red Star, 'Summer Solstice': Germans still shoot [...] still send their tanks against us. But they are no longer the same Germans. Water eats away a stone. Our resistance has eaten away the German sprit.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Jan-13-1942 | In order to warm up quicker, [Germans] burn furniture. They burn houses like bonfires. And then they freeze without shelter.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: Heinrich Himmler as Reichsführer-SS was assigned special tasks in the conquered areas, and would use Einsatzgruppen (task forces) of security police, which would eventually murder millions of civilians, including almost two million Soviet Jews.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.

text: By the end of 1941, the Germans had occupied Belorussia, the Baltic states, Crimea, and almost all of Ukraine; they surrounded Leningrad in what would become the longest siege in modern history; and they reached the outskirts of Moscow.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [In the very early days of the invasion,] head of the Soviet Information Bureau told me that I ought to write every day for the west, upon which I remarked that my articles were cut or not released at all by the Sovinformburo. This angered him: 'Well then you shouldn't try to be original.'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [re: Stalin's speech on 7-Nov-1941] I was shocked by his words about 'frightened little intellectuals.' Of course among the intelligentsia, too, there were some who'd lost their bearings, but no more so than among other sections of the population. I don't know why Stalin had once again to make a scapegoat of our intelligentsia.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: Foreigners were puzzled by the steadfastness of the Russians.[...] Some of them explained it by such cant phrases as 'Russian mysticism','long-suffering','oriental fatalism'.[After the Moscow counter-offensive an American journo:] 'It's no puzzle at all. It's the size of your territory that saved you.' I wasn't convinced.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [Surveying the files of old newspapers during the first five months of the German invasion,] Stalin's name was hardly ever mentioned. [... Seemed] Stalin had woken up to the fact that he had to make room for others.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [Lvov, Poland] In 1943, on Hitler's birthday, Obersturmführer Wilhaus, commandant of the Janowski camp, counted off fity-four inmates and shot them himself. Hitler was fifty-four that day.
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.
sourceChicago: World Jewish Congress, et al. The Black Book: The Nazi Crime Against the Jewish People. New York: Nexus Press, 1981.

text: Before the war about twenty-six thousand Jews lived in Brest [Belarus]; among them were engineers, physicians, technicians, lawyers, highly skilled carpenters. Of all those people, no more than fifteen miraculously survived the violence.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I., & Grossman, V. (Eds.). (1981). text: [Borisov, Belarus] An order was issued for Russians:'Upon meeting a Jew, cross to the other side of the street, greetings are forbidden, as is exchanging things.' For violating this order, Russians met the same fate as Jews.

text: Once they had occupied Odessa, the Hitlerites began first of all to eliminate the doctors. These professional murderers hated those whose calling was to lengthen the lives the lives of people and spare them suffering. In the very first days sixty-one doctors & their families were murdered: Rabinovich, Rubinstein, Varshavsky, ...

text: [Words of Yu. Farber, imprisoned Jewish worker @ Ponary killing site, Lithuania] Everything in me refused to accept this; it seemed unworthy to die a sheep's death. I was not the only one who felt this way. The thought of escape was everywhere. I was brought to Ponary on Jan.29 & by Feb.1 we'd already begun to [dig] a tunnel.

text: [Shavel Jewish Ghetto in Šiauliai, Lithuania] On March 24, 1943, the Shavel Judenrat met to discuss the problem that was in the most literal sense of the words one of life and death. On the order of business was: How to avoid child birth in the ghetto.
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.
sourceChicago: World Jewish Congress, et al. The Black Book: The Nazi Crime Against the Jewish People. New York: Nexus Press, 1981.

text: The bitter summer of 1942 set in. Names of new fronts occurred in the communiques: the Voronezh front, the Don front, the Stalingrad front, the Transcaucasian front. It was horrible to think that a Düsseldorfer was strolling about Pyatigorsk, that Magdeburg Burschen were gaping at the sands of Kalmukia. It was all unbelievable.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: Apr-25-1942 | Article in Red Star, 'A Patched Army': The German army has many tanks & mine-throwers, but it has no heart; it is an army of automatons. Slaves have hired other slaves, and slaves tell the slaves: 'Die for Hitler. We will give you some of the stolen bread. We will give you other people's towns.'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia., Translated by Alexander Kaun, A.A. Knopf, 1944.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The Tempering of Russia. Translated by Alexander Kaun. New York: A.A. Knopf, 1944.

text: I read that the futurist [Filippo Tommaso] Marinetti was on his way to Russia as he wanted to see how the Fascists were re-educating the muzhiks. This reminded of a line written by Marinetti long ago: 'My heart is made of red sugar.' [Marinetti was an associate of Mussolini.]
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [Spring 1942] In the morning someone knocked at my door. I saw a tall, sad-eyed youth in soldier's uniform. Many men from the front used to come asking me to write about their dead comrades or exploits [...] 'Sit down,' I said to the young man. He sat down but at once jumped up to announce:'I want to read you some poems.'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: In February 1945 [Semyon Gudzenko] wrote to me from the front: 'I am sending you five poems, some printable and some not. I'm writing a lot the whole time, my notebooks are full [...] If there are some poems that can be printed, it would be very nice [...] Censorship has taught me a lesson since my first poem'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941–1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [Odessa, Ukrain] The two Kantorovich sisters had connections with partisan detachments in near and distant catacombs. [Yelena and Olga] concealed a radio receiver an a typewriter. Summaries of broadcasts of the [Soviet Army] circulated about the city in a fashion that the [Germans and Rumanians] were unable to uncover.

The Rayak brothers told of how Shchebeko, a peasant, secretly brought milk to their sick mother daily.

text: [Nürnberg | 8th Nazi party congress | Sept-10-1936] Goebbels warns of a surprise attack from the East, as usual accusing the potential victim of planning precisely what the Nazis themselves will do, a twist that will explain their aggression on the grounds that the best defense is offense.[Germany attacked USSR on June-22-1941]
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.

text: Fritz Thyssen, with [Gustav & Alfried] Krupp, Papen, Stinnes, Siemens, Hugenberg and Schacht, was representatives of the industralists who financed the Nazi party. [Alfried was condemned to 12 years in prison but two years was issued an amnesty by the High Commissioner of the American zone of occupation.
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.
sourceChicago: World Jewish Congress, et al. The Black Book: The Nazi Crime Against the Jewish People. New York: Nexus Press, 1981.

text: [Report from Treblinka by Vasily Grossman] 'Achtung!' resounded over the mob [on the train station platform], and in the leaden silence the voice of the Scharfuehrer emitted the words repeated several times a day over a period of many months: Men remain here, women and children underess in the barracks on the left.
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.
sourceChicago: World Jewish Congress, et al. The Black Book: The Nazi Crime Against the Jewish People. New York: Nexus Press, 1981.

text: [Report from Treblinka by Vasily Grossman] Let us remember that fascism will emerge from this war not only with all the bitterness of defeat, but also with the sweet memory of the facility of mass murder. All of us to whom decency, freedom and the life of mankind are dear, must think of it daily and with great severity.
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.
sourceChicago: World Jewish Congress, et al. The Black Book: The Nazi Crime Against the Jewish People. New York: Nexus Press, 1981.

text: [Oct-24-1941|Vilna Ghetto, Lithuania] Under the leadership of two youths, Hauz and Goldstein, twenty jews barricaded themselves in a cellar on Hospital St [...] In an hour long battle, the twenty were killed, but not before they had strangled two of the Germans and wounded five of the police.
sourceAPA: World Jewish Congress. (1981). The Black book: The Nazi crime against the Jewish people. Nexus Press.
sourceChicago: World Jewish Congress, et al. The Black Book: The Nazi Crime Against the Jewish People. New York: Nexus Press, 1981.

text: I repeat: it is not I who matter. But amon the fity million victims of the Second World War one is absent: Fascism. It survived May 1945 [V-E Day]; for a time it sickened, it moped, but it's still alive [...] Fascism was born out of the greed & stupidity of some and of the perfidy & cowardice of others.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: In 1962 the Munich newspaper Soldatenzeitung launched a campaign against the publication of my memoirs in West Germany. Naturally it recalled the fictitious leaflet on the raping of German women; it threatened the publisher and referred to me as 'the greatest criminal in history.' [...] Ernst Junger supported the newspaper.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: Goebbels needed a bogey, so he spread the legend about the Jew Ilya Ehrenburg who thirsted to exterminate the German people [...] In an order dated 1st January 1945 Hitler himself condescended to mention me: 'Stalin's court lackey, Ilya Ehrenburg, declares that the German people must be exterminated.'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: The Nazis often wrote about me saying that I was fat, cross-eyed, with a hooked nose; that I was bloodthirsty; that in Spain I had stolen museum pieces to the value of fifteen million marks and sold them in Switzerland; that I employed the same stockbroker as Queen Wilhelmina of Holland ...
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: I believe I was one of the first to coin the collective nickname 'Fritz.' Here are the tiles of some short articles (I wrote one every day): Fritz as a Philosopher, Fritz the Narcissus, Fritz the Lecher, Fritz in 'Shmolengs', Fritz as a Mystic, Fritz as a Man of Letters, etc.—dozens, hundreds of them.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: I had to warn our soldiers that it was futile to rely on the solidarity of the German workers, to hope to awaken the conscience of Hitler's soldiers, that this was no time for trying to find 'good Germans' among the advancing enemy troops [...] I wrote:'Kill the German!'
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: I recall a sandy-haired, amiable-looking German; before the war he had worked in Düsseldorf where he had a family; he had thrown a Russian baby into a well because he suffered from insomnia [...] and the child had prevented him from falling sleep.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: I have held in my hand a cake of soap stamped with the legend 'pure Jewish soap,' prepared from the corpses of people who had been destroyed. But there is no need to speak of these things: thousands of books have been written about them.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [Feb-1943|Kursk, Russia] The Germans had stayed in Kursk for fifteen months [...] A house porter had made a lot of money: had had reported that the two old Jewesses were hiding in a cellar, thus winning favour with the Gestapo, was given a fine flat and was living in clover.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [Vasilyevichy, Belarus| Nov.1943] The peasants had hidden in the woods. The fascists caught thrity-seven people and killed them; they killed a very old man, S. K. Polonsky, and a thriteen-year-old boy, Adam Filimonov.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [As] they retreated, the Germans sawed or chopped down fruit-trees; I had seen it in 1916 in Picardy [during World War I] and I saw it again in 1943 in the Ukraine.
sourceAPA: Ehrenburg, I. (1964). The war, 1941-1945 (T. Shebunina, Trans.; in collaboration with Y. Kapp). New American Library.
sourceChicago: Ehrenburg, Ilya. The War, 1941-1945. Translated by Tatiana Shebunina in collaboration with Yvonne Kapp. New York: New American Library, 1964.

text: [During the war, the Soviet state] evacuated the industrial base from west to east, along with millions of [civilians subjected] to a compulsory labor draft and placed all workers under military discipline ... [implemented] a strict [food] rationing system.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Meyer Goldstein, a Red Army officer: [Many] could not survive evacuation to the east. My mother's sister Ita was in evacuation together with her in Yangiyul [Uzbekistan, where] she died from cold & starvation ... evacuation was extremely hard to bear ...
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Military historians widely acknowledge the critical role of the home front in the Red Army's ability ultimately to 'contain and then drive back' the Germans. In the words of one, 'no other population was asked to make this level of sacrifice.'
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: The output of every sector [metals/fuel/transport/food/consumer goods] was either converted or diverted to defense. [The USSR] had begun preparing for total war in the 1930s, when the state restricted consumption & adopted increasingly strict labor legislation. Soviet citizens [...] understood well that war was likely.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: [1939] Maksim Litvinov, Commissar of Foreign Affairs, made repeated offers of 'collective security' to France & Britain, proposing a united front against German aggression. [France and Britain assumed] Adolf Hitler's aims to be limited [... and declined] the Soviet offers in favor of a policy of appeasement.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Within 48 hrs of the German invasion, the Soviet for Evacuation was established. By fall 1942 it had organized the transport of  >2,400 industrial enterprises, ~8 million animals, & up to 25 million people. Its success, in inverse proportion to the losses on the battlefield, was responsible for the USSR's victory.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Many of these mobilizing efforts would have faltered without broad popular support & participation [of the Soviet citizens]. Evacuation rested wholly on the willingness of workers, even under bombardment, to dismantle, pack, & load the machines. After long/arduous journeys ... same workers reassembled factories.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: As the German invasion set millions of people across USSR in motion—evacuees/refugees/newly mobilized soldiers/deportees/workers—the Commissariat of Health struggled to contain typhus/dysentery/tuberculosis/measles/other deadly epidemics that swept through crammed trains/railway stations/ports.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Many people never knew or forgot that the vast majority of Hitler's troops were on the eastern front. The US and Britain didn't open the second front in Europe until June 6, 1944, well after the Soviet Union had already suffered devastating losses & its victory over the Nazis was almost assured.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: For the [USSR] Jewish population, the choice to leave [to east] or stay had particularly fateful consequences. Some heard rumors about the murderous behavior of the Germans but discounted the stories as exaggerated. Others, who had lived through World War I, remembered the Germans as 'cultured' & 'polite.'
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: As a young Jewish girl in Kiev, Raissa Smelaya remembered the split in her family when her aunt placed them on her factory's list for evacuation: My grandparents refused to evacuate. They said that they weren't afraid of the Germans and didn't believe what people said about their brutalities.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: The historian Yitzhak Arad notes that Soviet evacuation authorities rescued about 1.63 million Jews who otherwise would have been murdered by providing a safe haven in the east.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Central Committee's report on conditions in the eastern factories/mines: Arbitrariness & thievery rule the canteens. The workers are robbed twice. First, other contingents are fed on the stocks set aside for workers. Second, in all the investigated canteens, workers are short-weighted in the rudest [...] manner.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: The belief that [Soviet] officials were pilfering stocks was widely held, even by young & inexperienced workers. Recent vocational graduates working at factory No. 76 in Sverdlovsk wrote a joint letter to the regional newspaper in Jan-1943, charging that officials were stealing food & goods allocated to them.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Corruption flourished in the NKVD, which was responsible for policing food crimes. In 1944, the head of the Main Inspectorate of the Commissariat of Trade wrote about an investigation of Dal'stroi construction camps in the Far East that NKVD officials stole shamelessly from starving prisoners.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: During the war, the Soviet state created an unprecedented labor system, unique among the combatant nations. At no point before or after the war did the state hold so much power to command the labor of its citizens. The state mobilized almost 15 million free workers for permanent/temp work.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: The popular slogan, “All for the Front!” was everywhere during the war years, on posters, in newspaper articles, and on broad banners festooning streets and factories. The slogan was a literal description of how the needs of the front would upend the daily lives of ordinary people.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Labor shortage was a huge issue for all combatants countries. The US & Britain were able to staff their defense plants with waged workers who voluntarily chose to take new jobs. Germany & Japan used slave labor. The USSR, however, used a compulsory wartime labor draft.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Mariia Pechenegovksaia, a Komsomol member mobilized to work at the iron and steel plant in Zlatoust [Chelyabinsk, Russia | 1614 km from Moscow]: 'I know now what a mistake I made coming to this hell. The hunger is terrible, and every day they carry 18 or 19 coffins out of the factory.'
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: [During the War mobilization,] unlike World War I and the Civil War, when Russia was engulfed by vast epidemics of cholera, typhoid, and typhus along the refugee routes, public health officials managed to contain the worst outbreaks of lice- and water-borne diseases.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: Evacuation took an especially heavy toll on small children. The first major killer was the measles epidemic advancing from west to east along the rail lines used for evacuation. An even greater number died of starvation/diarrhea, and pneumonia contracted during evacuation or after arrival at their destination.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: [1940s in USSR] 40% of all doctors were in Moscow, Leningrad, and the cities of Ukraine, and peasants in rural areas still had little access to care. Moscow alone had the same number of doctors as the entire Volga region, the Urals, and Western Siberia combined.
sourceAPA: Goldman, W. Z., Filtzer, D. A. (2021). Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press.
sourceChicago: Goldman, Wendy Z.., Filtzer, Donald A.. Fortress Dark and Stern: The Soviet Home Front During World War II. United States: Oxford University Press, 2021.

text: The People Immortal, the first Soviet novel about the war, was serialized in Red Star in July/August (1942) to general acclaim. It was written by Vasily Grossman, who served as a journalist with Red Star covering all the main battles, from the defence of Moscow to the fall of Berlin.
sourceAPA: Grossman, V. (2022). The people immortal (R. Chandler & E. Chandler, Trans.; R. Chandler & J. Volohova, Introduction and Afterword). New York Review Books. (Original work published 1942).
sourceChicago: Vasily Grossman, The People Immortal, trans. Robert Chandler and Elizabeth Chandler, introduction and afterword by Robert Chandler and Julia Volohova (New York: New York Review Books, 2022). Originally published as Народ бессмертен (Moscow: Sovetsky Pisatel, 1942).
